Variables

TJS2 variables are specified using the var keyword. In TJS2, variables cannot be used without being declared.
The format for the var keyword is as follows:

var variableName;
Multiple variable names can also be specified by separating them with , (commas). If an initial value is required for a variable,

var variableName = initialValue;
Initial values can be assigned to variables using this format.

Example:
    var variable=0;
    var var2=variable+2;
    var var3="this is var3.";
    var var1,var2,var3;
    var a=0,b=1,c=3;

Variables do not need to have a type specified at declaration. They take the type of the value assigned to them. Additionally, types are automatically converted during calculations or based on context.

Variable Names

All identifiers are valid as variable names.

Example:
    var ampan;
    var 123a;  // NG because it starts with a number
    var function; // NG because function is a reserved word
    var function1; // OK because it contains a reserved word but is not the word itself
    var variable1; // So-called full-width characters can also be used

Redeclaration of Variables

Declaring a variable with the same name two or more times does not result in an error. However, if an initial value is specified in the second or subsequent declaration, that initial value is assigned to the variable. If no initial value is provided in the second or subsequent declaration, it becomes void.

Example:
    var a=0;
    var a; // Second declaration (no error, a becomes void)
    var a=-1; // Third declaration (no error, but -1 is assigned to a)

Variable Scope

Variables declared within a part enclosed by { } (a block) are valid only within that block, becoming local variables.
Also, unlike C, there are no restrictions on the position where variables can be declared.

Example:
    while(t--)
    {
        var ratio=t/all; // Declare variable 'ratio'
        setRatio(ratio);
    }

    // When control moves here, 'ratio' has been deleted

    var test; // Variables can be declared here as well

Additionally, if a variable with the same name as one outside the block is declared within the block, only the newly declared variable can be accessed within that block.

Example:
    var ratio=0;
    if(flag)
    {
        var ratio; // A variable with the same name as one declared outside the block

        ratio=buf.position / buf.totalTime; // Only the ratio within the block can be accessed
        setRatio(ratio);
    }

    // Exiting the block deletes the ratio inside the block, but the ratio outside remains
    ratio=-1;

Note
When a variable is declared with var outside of all scopes (called the global scope), that variable becomes a member of the global object.
